Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Instrument for Quantitative Characterization of Behavior of Magnetic Particles and Magnetically-Labeled Biomaterials in Emerging Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337860
Swihart

The PIs will develop an integrated multifunctional stand-alone instrument with unique capabilities for imaging, tracking, and characterizing coupled magnetic, thermal, transport, photonic and biofunctional properties and behavior of magnetic particles (MPs) and magnetically labeled biomaterials (MLBs), in situ, for a broad range of applications. The objectives are to integrate into one platform, state-of-the-art techniques that combine (i) the ability to track and characterize the dynamics of unlabeled MPs as small as 20 nm in diameter, (ii) high temporal resolution (up to 500,000 fps), and (iii) hyperspectral imaging (~2 nm wavelength resolution in the 400-900
nm range, pixel-by-pixel) with high optical resolution. They will co-develop and incorporate custom-designed magnetic field sources to produce prescribed 3D magnetic fields (for field-directed manipulation) and an RF source (for heating), combined with custom-designed magnetically-functional microfluidic flow cells that will produce controllable flow fields and enable sample manipulation during imaging. Custom user-friendly computational magneto-fluidics software will be integrated as part of the instrument to enable fundamental understanding and facilitate interpretation of experimental results. A highly interdisciplinary team of researchers with complimentary expertise will lead this effort. Development of the proposed instrument will advance fundamental understanding of physical properties and behavior of MPs and MLBs and the dynamics of interacting populations of such particles, in situ, under well-characterized and adjustable flow fields and in the presence of 3D static and low frequency and/or RF magnetic fields. Moreover, the instrument, with its integrated unique state-of-the-art capabilities, combining high resolution nanoparticle tracking and characterization, hyperspectral microscopy, thermal imaging and high frame rate imaging, represents a significant contribution to the fields of optical engineering, nanoparticle characterization, and bioimaging that will enable researchers to elucidate fundamental phenomena in fields that employ MPs/MLBs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) project aimed to develop new capabilities for the characterization of magnetic nanoparticles and magnetically-labelled biomaterials. Such materials are employed in an increasingly diverse array of applications, including separation of targeted cells from a mixture of cells and magnetically-guided or magnetically-enhanced drug delivery. Optimal implementation of these technologies requires fundamental understanding of the properties of the magnetic nanoparticles. A key parameter in this regard is something called the magnetophoretic mobility. This parameter tells us how fast a magnetic nanoparticle or biomaterial will move in response to an applied magnetic field. It depends upon the size, shape, and surface chemistry of the nanoparticle as well as the magnetic properties of the material from which it has been prepared. A key goal of this project was to integrate multiple types of optical microscopy with devices that can apply a controlled magnetic field. This would allow us to track the movement of magnetic nanoparticles and magnetically-labelled biomaterials and their response to applied magnetic fields. In addition to purchasing and integrating the equipment required for generating and measuring magnetic fields and for tracking nanoparticles, this required us to (1) develop new computational tools for analyzing the motion of interacting magnetic nanoparticles in a magnetic field; (2) develop new fabrication strategies to produce microfluidic devices (very small flow channels) with integrated magnetic components; and (3) develop new and improved methods for reproducible synthesis of magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles of well-controlled size and shape. This project has advanced the preparation and characterization of magnetic nanomaterials, microfluidic devices for manipulating them, and computational tools for predicting their motion and their assembly into ordered arrays and structures. These advances, along with the new characterization capabilities available through this project at the University at Buffalo (SUNY) will accelerate the development and implementation of important biomedical applications of magnetic nanomaterials.
